Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Perdigao: Multiscale Flow Interactions in Complex Terrain
Award.AbstractNarration:
Atmospheric flow through complex terrain is difficult to simulate due to the small scales of mountains and hills and the dependence of wind on a variety of factors, such as the temperature structure of the air near the ground. This award will allow a group of researchers the opportunity to join a large field campaign in Portugal and to supplement the experiment by deploying a large number of instruments. The project should result in a data set that will be used by numerical modelers for many years to come, with impacts on understanding boundary layer flows important to wind energy, air pollution, aviation, contaminant dispersion and alpine warfare. In addition, a number of students will have the opportunity to participate in the campaign and interact with international colleagues.

The Perdigao field campaign is part of a large European effort to improve the efficiency of wind energy production. This award will bring a basic research component to the effort, with a focus on studying interactions between flows of different scales, effects of topographic and diurnal thermal forcing, valley/slope boundary layers and turbine wakes. Instrumentation provided by this project will include multiple Lidars, a Tethered Lifting System, ceilometer, radiosonde system, anemometers, and the OU CLAMPS integrated mobile profiling system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project contributed to a large multi-national, multi-disciplinary project focused on improved understanding of flow in complex (mountainous terrain). Wind  flow in complex terrain is shaped by multiple scales of motion and is critical to improved siting of wind turbines, for air pollution, aviation safety and many other applications. An important aspect of this project was that it included an unprecedented diversity of instrumentation including a wide variety of remote sensing devices that can measure the flow at high-resolution (a few meters) over very large areas (many kilometers).

Our specific objectives were to develop new techniques for characterizing the flow field, using state-of-the-art lidar (light-detection and ranging), sonic anemometers deployed on tall masts and ground mounted seismometers and pressure sensors. All of the data collected by the Cornell University team were quality controlled and made data publicly available through the National Center for Atmospheric Research archive https://data.eol.ucar.edu/master_lists/generated/perdigao/ and the Incorporated Research Institutions for Seismology http://ds.iris.edu/ds/nodes/dmc/data/. These form part of a unique repository that is open to anyone interested in using the Perdig?o data to understand or characterize flow in complex terrain.

Our analyses resulted in the following key findings:

1)      Wind speeds are typically highest along ridge-tops. Hence wind turbines are often deployed along ridges. However, wind turbines along ridges are also subject to very gusty winds that can cause mechanical stresses. Our research has helped to derived methods to understand the relative costs and benefits of siting wind turbines on ridges. We also developed new algorithms to detect wind turbine wakes in lidar measurements and to determine how the wind turbine wakes behave in complex terrain. Like the water wake behind a motorboat, wind turbines create a wake of slower, more choppy air (a wake) behind each turbine that eventually spreads and recovers its momentum. A key consideration in developing wind turbine arrays (wind farms) is to reduce the frequency with which wind turbines are in the wake of upstream wind turbines. Thus our research that shows how wind turbine wakes move in complex terrain will help to build better wind farms in the future.

2)      The force on building and other structures scales with the square of wind speed so wind gusts are really important to wind-derived damage to human structures. Our research has improved understanding of how wind gusts occur in complex terrain and the size (in time and space) of these intermittent flow features. The gust patterns measured at Perdig?o have larger gust factors (ratios of maximum 3-second wind speed to the 10-minute mean wind speed) than those measured in less complex terrain but decrease with height at a rate similar to measurements over flat grassland. There was excellent agreement between measurements from instruments on meteorological masts with those from lidar. We also showed that wind gusts are detected by seismometers (instruments used to detect ground tremors and earthquakes) and improved methods to detect and remove wind gust noise from those time series.

During the project we trained two post-doctoral fellows and two graduate students and published 10 international journal publications on the data we collected. We organized special sessions on the Perdig?o experiment at three international conferences and gave 15 presentations at conferences and seminars. In addition to our blog and website, we were interviewed for radio, trade magazines, the journal Nature and the Portuguese newspaper ?Publico. We used the data as a basis for training in an Engaged Learning course at Cornell and for projects for Masters of Science/Engineering students.

Overall, this project was highly successful in advancing understanding of flow in complex terrain and produced scientific data needed for model development and evaluation in complex terrain. More than that, it was an excellent opportunity to collaborate in a large scientific team with colleagues from international institutions. We are very grateful to many people from the local community at Perdig?o, Portugal for the enormous amount of assistance they provided and to the National Science Foundation for funding our project.
